question.title: Gameboy emulation - SwingWorker stuck at Unsafe.park

node.contents: Do you HAVE to sleep in `vBlankOccured` method?

astNode.text: Do you HAVE to sleep in `vBlankOccured` method?

node.contents: Removing sleep did not help - I sleep to control how fast the CPU is running

astNode.text: Removing sleep did not help - I sleep to control how fast the CPU is running

node.contents: It was more curiosity than a probable fix ;)

astNode.text: It was more curiosity than a probable fix ;)

node.contents: I am making an emulator for the Gameboy system, and I am using Swing as my GUI. My implementation uses a SwingWorker to run the CPU emulation in a background thread. Through SwingWorker.doInBackground method I publish an array containing the framebuffer (the image data) at regular intervals (whenever the Gameboy emulates a VBlank screen refresh) which is supposed to happen ~60 times a second. I call on Thread.sleep(...) in this background thread to synchronize the Gameboys time with the system time. In the process method, I pass this data onto a JPanel and invoke its repaint method. My doInBackground method is basically an infinite loop with the emulated Gameboy CPU constantly stepping instructions in the background.

astNode.text: I am making an emulator for the Gameboy system, and I am using Swing as my GUI. My implementation uses a SwingWorker to run the CPU emulation in a background thread. Through SwingWorker.doInBackground method I publish an array containing the framebuffer (the image data) at regular intervals (whenever the Gameboy emulates a VBlank screen refresh) which is supposed to happen ~60 times a second. I call on Thread.sleep(...) in this background thread to synchronize the Gameboys time with the system time. In the process method, I pass this data onto a JPanel and invoke its repaint method. My doInBackground method is basically an infinite loop with the emulated Gameboy CPU constantly stepping instructions in the background.

node.contents: The problem I am facing is that on certain ROMs, my application just freezes and my JPanel component shows no screen updates. I tried using println's on my background running thread outputting the instruction being executed by the emulated CPU, and that is stuck as well with no output being generated after awhile.

astNode.text: The problem I am facing is that on certain ROMs, my application just freezes and my JPanel component shows no screen updates. I tried using println's on my background running thread outputting the instruction being executed by the emulated CPU, and that is stuck as well with no output being generated after awhile.

node.contents: With some ROMs, I don't see this issue happening at all.

astNode.text: With some ROMs, I don't see this issue happening at all.

node.contents: Here is a sample of my SwingWorker code:

astNode.text: Here is a sample of my SwingWorker code:

elements.contents: package com.sankar.gbemu.swing; import com.sankar.gbemu.cpu.CPU; import com.sankar.gbemu.gpu.LCDController; import com.sankar.gbemu.gpu.VBlankListener; import java.util.List; import javax.swing.SwingUtilities; import javax.swing.SwingWorker; public class EmulationWorker extends SwingWorker<Void,int[][]> { private CPU cpu; private LCDController lcd; private GBPanel panel; private GBRenderer renderer; public EmulationWorker(CPU cpu, LCDController lcd, GBPanel panel, GBRenderer renderer) { this.cpu = cpu; this.lcd = lcd; this.panel = panel; this.renderer = renderer; init(); } private void init() { lcd.registerVBlankListener(new VBlankListener() { private long lastRefresh = System.nanoTime(); private static final long REFRESH_INTERVAL = (long)1e9/60; @Override public void vBlankOccured(int[][] screenData) { publish(screenData); long currentTime = System.nanoTime(); long delta = currentTime - lastRefresh; lastRefresh = currentTime; if (delta < REFRESH_INTERVAL) { try { long sleepInterval = (long)((REFRESH_INTERVAL - delta)/1e6); Thread.sleep(sleepInterval); } catch(InterruptedException e) { // Ignore } } } }); } @Override protected Void doInBackground() throws Exception { while(true) cpu.step(); } @Override protected void process(List<int[][]> updates) { if (!SwingUtilities.isEventDispatchThread()) throw new RuntimeException("Not in event dispatch thread"); renderer.updateScreenData(updates.get(updates.size() - 1)); panel.repaint(); } }

comments.text: // Ignore } } } }); } @Override protected Void doInBackground() throws Exception { while(true) cpu.step(); } @Override protected void process(List<int[][]> updates) { if (!SwingUtilities.isEventDispatchThread()) throw new RuntimeException("Not in event dispatch thread"); renderer.updateScreenData(updates.get(updates.size() - 1)); panel.repaint(); } }

node.contents: I'm not sure what could possibly be wrong since all my Swing component updates are being done only on the EventDispatch thread.

astNode.text: I'm not sure what could possibly be wrong since all my Swing component updates are being done only on the EventDispatch thread.

node.contents: I am running Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_40-b43) for Mac OS X Mountain Lion which is the latest version that was available.

astNode.text: I am running Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_40-b43) for Mac OS X Mountain Lion which is the latest version that was available.

node.contents: The doInBackground method was actually throwing an exception. Since I did not implement the done method and obtain the result using get, the exception was swallowed and went unnoticed.

astNode.text: The doInBackground method was actually throwing an exception. Since I did not implement the done method and obtain the result using get, the exception was swallowed and went unnoticed.

node.contents: Personally I would not use publish for this kind of thing. The docs on it provide a fairly detailed explanation of how it works:

astNode.text: Personally I would not use publish for this kind of thing. The docs on it provide a fairly detailed explanation of how it works:

node.contents: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/swing/SwingWorker.html#publish(V...)

astNode.text: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/swing/SwingWorker.html#publish(V...)

node.contents: When you send a value to publish, process is not necessarily called immediately. The EDT combines multiple publish calls in to the single list chunk you get in process. If you call publish 60 times in a second, you probably won't get 60 calls to process. In fact you might get only one call to process with all 60 frames in the list.

astNode.text: When you send a value to publish, process is not necessarily called immediately. The EDT combines multiple publish calls in to the single list chunk you get in process. If you call publish 60 times in a second, you probably won't get 60 calls to process. In fact you might get only one call to process with all 60 frames in the list.

node.contents: Just do your frame updates from inside doInBackground. Publish is meant for returning data like progress updates for long tasks and chunks from a database. Repaint is automatically called with invokeLater (whether you like it or not) so it is safe to do outside of the EDT.

astNode.text: Just do your frame updates from inside doInBackground. Publish is meant for returning data like progress updates for long tasks and chunks from a database. Repaint is automatically called with invokeLater (whether you like it or not) so it is safe to do outside of the EDT.

node.contents: I also do not see what the cpu.step method does but seeing as how it is in a while(true) indicates to me that your freeze may be happening because of that. There is not really an exact way to control FPS in Java but you need to be doing your Thread.sleep or Swing Timer inside the game loop.

astNode.text: I also do not see what the cpu.step method does but seeing as how it is in a while(true) indicates to me that your freeze may be happening because of that. There is not really an exact way to control FPS in Java but you need to be doing your Thread.sleep or Swing Timer inside the game loop.

node.contents: cpu.step -> calls publish -> calls process -> calls vBlankOccurred where your sleep is

astNode.text: cpu.step -> calls publish -> calls process -> calls vBlankOccurred where your sleep is

node.contents: the while(true) in doInBackground is not sleeping and your frame updates are running wild:

astNode.text: the while(true) in doInBackground is not sleeping and your frame updates are running wild:

node.contents: SwingWorker should yield to the EDT but maybe it isn't for some reason. Try doing your frame updates without publish and see what happens.

astNode.text: SwingWorker should yield to the EDT but maybe it isn't for some reason. Try doing your frame updates without publish and see what happens.

node.contents: Also in my experience, frame control in Java is tricky. The EDT does something similar with repaints as it does with process. If too many repaints are called, the EDT combines them in to a single update. I know for a fact that on OS X Snow Leopard this means without explicit frame control you get about a choppy 15FPS with blocky shapes from an amalgam of interim repaints. Thread.sleep like you're doing is correct as far as I know but it's a behavior to be aware of if you are doing a game loop with Swing repaints. Whether or not Swing actually does it, Swing is allowed to.

astNode.text: Also in my experience, frame control in Java is tricky. The EDT does something similar with repaints as it does with process. If too many repaints are called, the EDT combines them in to a single update. I know for a fact that on OS X Snow Leopard this means without explicit frame control you get about a choppy 15FPS with blocky shapes from an amalgam of interim repaints. Thread.sleep like you're doing is correct as far as I know but it's a behavior to be aware of if you are doing a game loop with Swing repaints. Whether or not Swing actually does it, Swing is allowed to.
